description: Originally of tears; perhaps from strickle, frequentative of to strike (perhaps from merging/metanalysis of 's' in tears strickle).
For other similar cases of incorrect division, see also apron, daffodil, newt, nickname, orange, umpire.

examples: The brook had shrunk to a mere trickle.

entries.meaning: A very thin flow; the act of trickling.
examples: The tap of the washbasin in my bedroom is leaking and the trickle drives me mad at night.

verbs.description: trickle (third-person singular simple present trickles, present participle trickling, simple past and past participle trickled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to pour a liquid in a very thin stream, or so that drops fall continuously.
examples: The doctor trickled some iodine on the wound.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) to flow in a very thin stream or drop continuously.
examples: Here the water just trickles along, but later it becomes a torrent.
The film was so bad that people trickled out of the cinema before its end.
